text: And God Almighty bless thee, and make thee fruitful, and multiply thee, that thou mayest be a multitude of people;
text_kjv: And God Almighty bless thee, and make thee fruitful, and multiply thee, that thou mayest be a multitude of people;
text_niv: May God Almighty bless you and make you fruitful and increase your numbers until you become a community of peoples.
text_esv: God Almighty  bless you and make you fruitful and multiply you, that you may become a company of peoples.
text_nlt: May God Almighty bless you and give you many children. And may your descendants multiply and become many nations!
text_msg: "And may The Strong God bless you and give you many, many children, a congregation of peoples;
text_nasb: 'May God Almighty bless you and make you fruitful and multiply you, that you may become a company of peoples.
context: Genesis 28:3 occurs during a pivotal moment in Jacob's life. He is fleeing from his brother Esau, whom he has deceived to steal his birthright and blessing. Isaac, now elderly and possibly sensing his impending death, sends Jacob to Paddan-aram, to the house of Bethuel, his mother Rebekah's father, to find a wife from among his relatives. This was crucial, as marrying Canaanite women was frowned upon and seen as spiritually compromising. Isaac's blessing upon Jacob is therefore not just a personal wish but a reaffirmation and continuation of the Abrahamic covenant. The phrase 'God Almighty,' translated from 'El Shaddai,' is significant. 'El' represents God's power and might, while 'Shaddai' is more complex, possibly relating to breasts or nourishment, implying God's provision and care, or mountains, reflecting God's unshakeable power. This blessing connects Jacob to his lineage and reinforces the promise made to Abraham that his descendants would become a great nation. Marriage within the family was also a customary way to keep the family lineage pure and protect inheritance rights. Leaving Canaan and returning to Rebekah's family also represented a return to the spiritual roots of the family. The blessing is spoken within this context of familial duty, divine promise, and Jacob's precarious situation. This verse demonstrates the patriarchal societal structure, where the father's blessing held immense weight for the future of his sons.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 28:3 is loaded with significance. The blessing invokes 'God Almighty' (El Shaddai), emphasizing God's sovereign power and ability to fulfill His promises. The request for fruitfulness and multiplication directly echoes God's initial command to humanity in Genesis 1:28, 'Be fruitful and multiply.' This repetition connects Jacob's blessing to God's original intent for creation and highlights the ongoing nature of God's plan for humanity. The promise that Jacob would become 'a multitude of people' is a direct fulfillment of the Abrahamic covenant (Genesis 12:2, 17:6, 22:17). God is reiterating His commitment to Abraham through Jacob, ensuring the continuation of the chosen line through whom the Messiah would eventually come. The blessing also subtly addresses Jacob's deceitful actions. While he obtained the blessing through trickery, God's faithfulness is not contingent on Jacob's moral perfection. Instead, it underscores God's sovereign grace and His ability to work through flawed individuals to accomplish His purposes. The 'multitude of people' is not merely about numbers; it also points to the spiritual implications of the covenant. Jacob's descendants would not only be numerous but would also become a nation that would bless all the nations of the earth (Genesis 12:3). The blessing, therefore, foreshadows the future of Israel and its role in God's redemptive plan.
application: In modern life, Genesis 28:3 offers several practical applications. First, it reminds us to seek God's blessing in all aspects of our lives, not just in family matters, but also in our careers, relationships, and personal growth. We should actively pray for fruitfulness, not just in terms of physical offspring, but also in our endeavors, talents, and spiritual development. Are we using our gifts to contribute positively to the world? Are we striving to make a difference in the lives of others? Secondly, the verse encourages us to see our lives as part of a larger story â€“ God's ongoing plan for humanity. Like Jacob, we are often flawed and make mistakes, but God's promises are not nullified by our imperfections. We can find comfort and hope in the fact that God can use even our weaknesses to accomplish His purposes. We must ask ourselves how we can become a blessing to others. This could involve acts of kindness, service, or sharing our resources with those in need. The idea of becoming a multitude of people can also be applied metaphorically. We can influence many people through our actions and words, shaping the world around us in positive ways. Finally, the emphasis on family reminds us of the importance of nurturing healthy relationships and investing in the lives of our loved ones. Isaac's concern for Jacob's future family is a model for us. How are we building strong family bonds and passing on our values to the next generation? Genesis 28:3 is a call to embrace God's blessings, live purposefully, and become a source of blessing to others, both individually and collectively, striving to be fruitful in all we do and contributing to a world shaped by God's love and justice.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your promise to bless us and make us fruitful. We acknowledge that you are the 'God Almighty,' El Shaddai, the source of all power and provision. We humbly ask for your blessing upon our lives, that we may be fruitful in all our endeavors and that we may multiply your love and grace in the world. Forgive us for our shortcomings and imperfections, and help us to trust in your sovereign plan, even when we face challenges and uncertainties. Grant us wisdom to use our gifts and talents to serve others and to make a positive impact on the world. Strengthen our families and relationships, and help us to pass on our values to the next generation. May our lives be a testament to your faithfulness and may we become a blessing to all those around us. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: 'El Shaddai' is often translated as 'God Almighty' but has deeper connotations. 'El' signifies God's power, while 'Shaddai' is linked to nourishment and sustenance, possibly 'God of the mountains'. Its use emphasizes God's power to fulfill promises and provide abundantly, reassuring Jacob during his vulnerable journey.

faqs.answer: Fruitfulness encompasses more than just children. It refers to productivity, growth, and positive impact in all areas of life, including careers, relationships, spiritual development, and the use of one's gifts and talents to serve others and glorify God.
faqs.question: Q4: How can the concept of 'fruitfulness' be interpreted beyond literal offspring?

faqs.answer: This blessing carries the responsibility to live a life worthy of God's favor and to become a blessing to others. It calls for purposeful action, using resources and abilities to positively influence the world, reflecting God's love and promoting justice.
